Author: haythem1666

Author: raulj
Content: @Haythem sol storage! Lets you write solidity code within to define structs that will be translated into rust code that is storage backed. #[solidity_storage] can be added directly to rust structs to give them storage backings

Content: @Haythem all good, we‚Äôre excited for you to look more into the sdk! Result means something can fail. It will either return an address or an error. The error type is a vector of bytes

Content: Result is a common rust pattern for error handling

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: We're going to soon let it be just `Address` if the method is infallible. The SDK is a work in progress, and we're super interested in whatever friction you run into

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Btw we're about to roll out an upgrade to the hello-world contract in around an hour that'll cut costs. We mistakenly configured a large stack size

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
If you want it early, add
```rs
[target.wasm32-unknown-unknown]
rustflags = [

]
```
to your `.cargo/config`

Author: haythem1666
Content: I don't get the `setter` function, it is meant to set value in storage right?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Almost, it gives you a handle to a slot in storage, which you can then use to set the value

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Although you can often just `.set` directly

Author: haythem1666
Content:
~~Ah, so it is only used for mapping? and vars like bool and uint256 can use .set directly?~~

Why when updating `balance` in the erc20, it uses .setter to get that slot and then .set, vs when changing total_supply it just used .set()?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Oh oops, we should change that, nice catch

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: This is great feedback, much appreciated

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: :Stylus:

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Oh looking at it now, in `transfer_impl` what's happening is we're using the setter to call `get`

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
Like you'll see in the comments, we're going to make storage manipulation much prettier. Ideally you'd just do
```rs
self.balances[address] -= value;
```

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: But right now it's a bit verbose

Author: haythem1666
Content: so I can't just do now `self.balances.get(address)` ?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: You can

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Our method documentation on docs.rs is generating right now, but soon you'll have a page where you can browse all the methods

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: In `self.balances` case, you'd see it's a `StorageMap`, and then be able to look at all the methods of `StorageMap` with comments detailing what they do

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
We're 57th in the queue here üôÇ
https://docs.rs/releases/queue

Author: plasmapower
Content: If you want to get a head start you can check out the `stylus-sdk-rs` repo locally and run `cargo doc` üôÇ

Author: haythem1666
Content: so what's the diff between `self.balances.get(address)` and using `setter() + .get()` ? if they are the same, what's the reason between ur decision to use setter() + .get() ?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Great point!

Author: haythem1666
Content: okay make sense will stop asking for now and check doc later üòÑ

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: We re-use the setter to do `.get` and then `.set`. We could have split that

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Oh actually it also lets you hold the same storage slot instead of hashing twice

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: So it's a minor performance optimization too that nets around 30 gas

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Just to be clear though, we're going to rework this so that it's more straightforward üôÇ

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Thanks for bearing with us!

Author: haythem1666
Content: for constructor, should I just do `pub fn new...` under `#[external] impl....` ?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: That's def a way to do it, though just be careful you're the first one to call the method. Otherwise someone else might initialize your contract

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: We recommend deploying and calling it in the same tx

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Though testnet's not so adversarial -- you're safe to just call the thing in a follow-up tx haha

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
That‚Äôs not really the intended use case for storage variables. In our model you declare your contract‚Äôs storage, and then have access to it in the entrypoint.

If you do want to declare storage yourself, you can use the `unsafe` `StorageAddress::new()` method, likely on the input 0,0

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: We'll improve this error message, but what's really happening here is that there's no entrypoint, so it's not deployable on chain üôÇ

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Your code looks like a library, which other people might import to use in their contracts. That's awesome and very powerful, but in order for your code to be used on chain by itself, it'll need to instead have an `#[entrypoint]` somewhere

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: So what you could do is add a `main.rs` file, import your file, and then add an entrypoint that uses the Ownable mechanism you've implemented

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Does that make sense?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: :sayori:

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Notice how the `erc20.rs` example has a corresponding `main.rs`, which declares a type that then uses `#[entrypoint]` and `#[inherit]` to use the `Erc20`

Content: Ah yeah, make sense, thnx

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: We plan to ship `v0.2.0` today, which should include a fix for this among other improvements!

Author: raulj
Content: Deploying Stylus programs to the testnet is a two-step process. You must first deploy your raw, compressed WASM code onchain. Then, you will need to send a follow-up tx that "activates" that WASM code. This activation process will compile the wasm code into a form that can be executed by our runtime. The nice thing is that if two people deployed the same code to different addresses, only one activation is necessary

Author: raulj
Content: Our `cargo stylus` tool does all this for you when you do `cargo stylus deploy` üôÇ

Author: raulj
Content: Solidity ABI exports for our C sdk are not yet supported, but are totally doable in the future. At this time, if you want to use the siphash example, you will probably just have to send raw bytes via an eth_call to the siphash contract deployed onchain. The raw bytes start with a 16 byte key, followed by the input bytes you want to hash

Author: raulj
Content: ill put together an example of how to interact with the siphash contract in Rust using ethers-rs to talk to the Stylus testnet

Author: raulj
Content: @Zk , Rachel has also suggested that you could just include siphash in your C contracts that you want to deploy, as it is only 609 bytes so there is no size concern. However, if you want to just deploy siphash and call it, you would need to do it the way I mentioned above

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Siphash is super small -- I'd just include it in your dapp directly. There's no need to introduce the overhead of calling out to another contract for something so tiny

Author: 0xren_cf
Content: reading through stylus (had a few questions). is the right way to think about it that the rust wasm can read/write storage slots? how does the wasm side handle memory expansion? what happens to the call trace for stylus smart contract calls? does the wasm have a way to get transpiled into MIPs to generate fraud proofs?

Author: zklim
Content: I see, let me test out some custom code using eth_call and see how's it going

Author: chrisco512
Content:
> is the right way to think about it that the rust wasm can read/write storage slots? 

that's part of it, yes; the Rust wasm is accessing the equivalent storage slots that a Solidity contract would be accessing on the EVM. both Solidity contracts and Rust wasm contracts share the same state trie

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: The WASM the Rust is compiled to is fraud proven directly, rather similar to how we prove fraud over geth üôÇ

Author: chrisco512
Content: re: memory expansion, the wasm expands memory one page at a time (64 KB pages); there is a separate pricing model for the wasm vm but I don't think we have it documented yet

Author: jtriley
Content: what about `"vm_hooks"`? i'm seeing it in tests as an import, but i'm not seeing much about it. it seems to expose an evm-like interface, but is it something i need to install to compile a wat or assemblyscript file?

Author: raulj
Content: Hi @jtriley these are imports that are provided to stylus wasm programs. For example, some of then allow you to grow memory, or read input args, or write output data to a caller. These are quite low level details we have yet to document

Author: raulj
Content: For example, heres how I added support for the zig programming language using these imports https://github.com/rauljordan/zig-on-stylus/blob/main/src/lib.zig

Author: raulj
Content: Ill share a tutorial on how to add new languages soon, hopefully next week

Author: raulj
Content: These imports will be injected into your program by our wasm runtime

Content: @jtriley curious, so are you working on trying to get AssemblyScript working with Stylus?

Content: no, just wat; wanna get a gas diff between wat and rs

Author: chrisco512
Content: sorry for missing this earlier; we don't have light clients in the real sense of the word, but you can run a node locally: https://docs.arbitrum.io/node-running/how-tos/running-a-full-node also see the dev node section if you need a dev node. However, note that we don't yet have a docker image for Stylus

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: We don't modify wasmer, but rather escape the wasm client to native execution in the host via special imports

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: That's why they're called Host I/Os

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: You leave wasm execution, and jump into the VM

Author: jtriley
Content: makes sense. ty for your help ü´°

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
Hey all, we just rolled out our first hot-fix to the Stylus testnet. We've reorged the chain in response to an issue around how we handled WASMs without memories. Here's the PR
- https://github.com/OffchainLabs/stylus/pull/141

As a reminder the Stylus testnet and SDKs are in alpha, and so reorgs and regenesis are expected until Stylus approaches mainnet readiness.

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
:air: 
Btw we've just rolled out a new version of `cargo stylus` that has better error messages. You can upgrade your tooling via
```sh
cargo install --force cargo-stylus
```

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: We'll soon release v0.2.0 of the Rust SDK too based on feedback from users

Content:
You should generally consider debug-mode to be disabled and, accordingly, CONSOLE macros to be invalid.

Author: seanpa0
Content:
hey, I see that `memory_grow` is called only in `mark_used`. Are there any calls of it under the hood by the Rust standard library that I am missing? Probably this is how the wasm grows its linear memory. 
I was wondering since it is only called in `mark_used`. If that's the case, what is the idea behind having them both imported and exported in the first place?

Author: elsie_19
Content: Issue solved, I only change my browser

Author: ecowealth
Content: Left me hanging

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: `memory_grow` is the function that makes you pay to invoke the `memory.grow` WASM opcode. Any WASM that intends to grow must import the function in the Stylus VM

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: `mark_used` exists solely to force the Rust compiler to import the symbol. A similar trick is done in the C/C++ SDK to force its import as well

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: :air:

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
[A new version of the SDK is out btw!](https://github.com/OffchainLabs/stylus-sdk-rs/releases)
You can import it by updating your `Cargo.toml`
```toml
stylus-sdk = "0.2.4"
```

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
You may need to update Rust for this version. You can do this via
```sh
rustup upgrade
cargo install --force cargo-stylus
```

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: No, your language‚Äôs compiler will generate `memory.grow` opcodes for you

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: If you call it manually, it‚Äôll just burn gas without actually growing the memory

Author: w3tester
Content: @Rachel üíô | Offchain Labs we understand there is a size limit for the stylus wasm program. It turns out our program is much larger than this limit‚Äîabout 1024KB. My question is: will this limit be lifted in the future? If not, it seems our only option is to make our program as a pre-compile and run it in our Orbit chain?

Author: sica4068
Content: Stylus is undergoing major upgrades, and some improvements are expected to require a chain reset.

Author: sica4068
Content: Excuse meÔºåwill the cross-chain bridge eth to stylus be reset now?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Stylus is testnet only right now and sits on top of Arbitrum Sepolia. There‚Äôs no ETH bridge that I‚Äôm aware of

Author: sica4068
Content: i mean,Arbitrum Sepolia to Stylus testnet

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
Yes, we‚Äôre working on binary sizes in a few ways
- We‚Äôre improving the Rust SDK to make binaries smaller
- We‚Äôre adding more features to the C SDK, which produces much smaller binaries
- We‚Äôre working on increasing the contract size limit. It‚Äôs unclear yet if we‚Äôll be able to allow contracts of that size (if we did, it‚Äôd be an unlimited policy where you‚Äôd pay more the larger the binary was)

For something so large, your options right now are to
- Create Orbit precompiles, which have no limit, allow SIMD and floating point, are lower fee, etc
- Split your code over multiple contracts / optimize your binary (probs not worth it given 1024Kb is pretty far away from the 128Kb limit)

Something I‚Äôm curious about is how compressible your contract is. I‚Äôm assuming that number is 1 megabyte before compression, but what is it after applying brotli 11?

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Yes, if you don‚Äôt bridge out (takes 20 mins) you‚Äôll lose your testnet ether. We‚Äôll give everyone a heads up when we schedule upgrades

Author: patrickalphac
Content:
Btw, devrel tip - I highly encourage people to post questions on a forum like Peeranha / Ethereum Stack Exchange. 

For the following reasons:
1. The questions will be indexed by web crawlers so that they show in web search results (discord does not)
2. AIs that train on stack exchange will learn from the Q&A of such forums, meaning people who use AIs can then have better conversations

I have created a `stylus` tag on Stack Exchange ETH if anyone is interested in following it so that other devs can find the answers and be better for it üôÇ

Author: patrickalphac
Content:
Yeah I think this is the answer, but I couldn't figure out where the `no_std` section was. 

We have this line:

```
#![cfg_attr(not(feature = "export-abi"), no_main)]
```

but I wasn't able to figure out if that *also* meant `no_std` somehow.

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
Hey everyone, [a new version of the Stylus SDK is out](https://github.com/OffchainLabs/stylus-sdk-rs/releases)!

To upgrade to the latest version, edit your `Cargo.toml` as follows
```toml
stylus-sdk = "0.4.1"
```

Author: glazec
Content: How can we enable reentrant for stylus?

Author: ainmox
Content: Feature flag

Author: ainmox
Content: https://docs.arbitrum.io/stylus/reference/rust-sdk-guide#reentrancy

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
It‚Äôs indeed a feature flag
```toml
stylus-sdk = { version = ‚Äú0.4.1‚Äù, features = [‚Äúreentrant‚Äù] }
```

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: There‚Äôs other flags too!

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
Btw introducing reentrancy with the default feature flags on will change the API a bit, since you have to be careful to flush the storage cache when making calls, among other safety considerations.

Some users may prefer to only opt into the features they want, which you can do via
```toml
stylus-sdk = { version = ‚Äú0.4.1‚Äù, no-default-features = true, features = [‚Äúreentrant‚Äù] }
```

Content: is there a way to run wasm's > 128KB on a local chain (for testing)?

Author: macmacmacprime
Content:
```uncompressed WASM program size (190.2 KB)
```
trying:

```
cargo +nightly build -Z build-std=std,panic_abort -Z build-std-features=panic_immediate_abort
```
&&
```
wasm-opt --enable-nontrapping-float-to-int --enable-typed-function-references --enable-gc --enable-reference-types --enable-exception-handling  --inline-functions-with-loops --traps-never-happen --fast-math
```

Author: cryptoiscute
Content:
Yes, we're working on increasing limits for an upcomming upgrade, but for now what you can do is edit the following two lines in the node software

https://github.com/OffchainLabs/stylus/blob/fc0a69d9a9e9fecfa7ae7ed028d16fc84b4ee62a/arbos/programs/programs.go#L63

https://github.com/OffchainLabs/stylus-geth/blob/27113b8c17690a445e8d66b5988d5e34b42a574f/params/protocol_params.go#L127

Author: cryptoiscute
Content: Feel free to change those to whatever you like -- we're working on a model where larger contracts are possible.

Content:

cargo stylus check -e http://localhost:8545
```
